Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: third-party bank check, setting aside whether an

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: issuer or processor could be a third party in 1974, and it can't for the reasons the experts explain, but these instruments don't even meet Delaware's own definition of a bank check.  So Delaware says that in order to be a third- party

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: As I mentioned earlier when we were

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: discussing teller's checks, a -- a -- a bank

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: check -- and this is -- is really you've only

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: This is at page 37 of their exceptions

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: where they say that a -- a bank check is an

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: instrument that's signed by a bank officer, and, as I said before, they stopped reading at that point, but it actually says drawing on funds deposited in the officer's own bank, that's a classic cashier's check, or drawing on funds of the officer's bank deposited in another financial institution.  That's a classic or traditional teller's check.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Again, that does not describe these

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: instruments here.  When the bank officer signs, one, he's signing as an agent of MoneyGram.  To the extent that's not already obvious as a functional matter, the contracts between MoneyGram and the financial institutions make very clear the financial institution is an agent of MoneyGram.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: instruments don't meet that definition because it's --it's not signing to draw on any funds

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: that are in any control of the selling bank.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Instead, it's MoneyGram that has the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: money, and it's MoneyGram that is responsible

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: for paying the drawee bank or for reporting the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: both those -- that technical definition that I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: just mentioned but also ordinary checks.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Or -- in -- in the 1970s going all the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: way back until World War I, "bank check" had been used as a terminology -- used as a term under Brady's Law of Bank Checks to both mean those -- those specific instruments issued by banks but also ordinary checks, and that's part of why a third -party bank check ultimately, what

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: that phrase means if we're in the "similar written instrument" provision, is an ordinary check.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: I got reading your arguments and your friend's argument is that nobody has much of an idea what a third- party bank check is.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Is that -- is that a fair --

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: MR. BRONNI: -- we are -- we are,

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: however, stuck with -- with two things. We have

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: to at least try and figure out what the terminology could have meant using similar phraseology in the 1970s, and, you know, again,

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: it --they've agreed that it has to at least be

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: But, in --in --in terms of what the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: entire phrase could have meant, again, you --this is another example where I think you've only been offered two realistic options based in the way similar phraseology was used in the 1970s, neither one of which would describe these instruments.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: So Delaware says that a -- that in the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: phrase third- party bank check, the third party

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: and check got used in the 1970s was in the context of third -party payment services or

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: in the 1970s to refer to an outside issuer or processor.  And what that means is they've

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: offered a definition that is no way anchored with the way the terminology was used in the 1970s.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Text: And I think the -- defining a

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: third-party bank check as an ordinary check

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I

Text: with that -- that sort of legislative history.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR:  Thank you. CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS:  Justice Kagan?

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Justice Jackson? JUSTICE JACKSON:  One final question. So Justice Kagan pointed out that

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Congress might have been intending to cover the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: field with this statute.  And I guess my question is, so what --what is the field? It

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: seems as though your friend says that really

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Congress was worried about no addresses, and, as a result, large- money instruments wouldn't fit

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: in the statute because there was an incentive to have addresses.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: And I understood you to be focusing on

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Congress's be -- concern about inequitable escheatment, in which case these instruments would be covered.  So can you just, as a final word here, talk about what the purpose of this statute is?

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: MR. BRONNI: I -- I -- I -- well, I'll

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: start with the purpose of the statute is to address those instruments that presented the windfall inequity problem associated with the Court's common law rule.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: I think what they're suggesting is

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: there would be an incentive to keep addresses

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: case is a prime example of that hasn't happened. These are larger -dollar instruments, and

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: And it's the -- the -- the point here

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: is that it's the issuer. It's the party that is actually responsible for paying these instruments. It's the party that holds the unclaimed property.  And it hasn't kept those --

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: address information.  So, I mean, to the extent Delaware's suggesting that that somehow makes a difference here, the record just doesn't bear that out.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: But, again, going back to the -- the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: -- the other point about -- you know, Congress's

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: actual concern was not just the low- dollar

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: instruments.  Congress's concern was that requiring addresses to be kept for money orders as a class of instruments and other similar written instruments would be an additional burden that is not justified in light of the fact that people buy these instruments where they do their banking.  They buy them in their home state.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: So, if you required addresses and all

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: the burdens that go along with that, it's simply going to reflect the same place. So what

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Congress is saying in 2501 is, to use Learned Hand's phrase, the game is not worth the candle here. Congress just decided it was easier just to have these instruments escheat to the state of purchase, regardless of what their value

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: JUSTICE JACKSON:  Thank you. CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Thank you,

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Rebuttal, Mr. Katyal? REBUTTAL ARGUMENT OF NEAL K. KATYAL

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: MR. KATYAL: Thank you, Mr. Chief

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: First, as the Chief Justice said, they

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: can solve this problem easily by saying MoneyGram has to have the information.  The information's already being collected by the banks. The only question is closing that informational hi ccup. And that's a lot better,

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Justice Sotomayor, than the instrument -by-instrument litigation that will be

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: His answer to that was -- to say to

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: the Chief Justice, was, well, Congress put its thumb on the scale.  They did with respect to

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: those two instruments.  The question in this case is, did they do so for anything more than that? And the reasons why Congress isolated

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: those two instruments don't apply here.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: The other point is Congress is the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: solution to this.  Even if you don't think states will have this easy fix, which I can't understand to this day why they haven't done it, but Congress can, of course, do that.  That's what you said in the Delaware case in 1993.  If you're worried about equity concerns, Congress should fix it. And what did you point to in that --in that decision?  You literally pointed

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: to 2503 and said that's the solution if you're worried about equity concerns.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: banks, my friend says that there's no expert testimony that supports our position.  That's a misreading of the record.  The expert, Ron Mann, just didn't support our position on the words "directly liable" back down below.  As this case

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: comes to the Court, we agree Professor Mann was

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: "third-party bank check," I think, Mr. Chief

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Justice, you said, well, nobody really knows what it means. We actually think the Hunt Commission does know what it means, and they

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: told you what it means in that report, and that says teller's checks are included.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Now my friend says --this is our

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: third point -- that cashier's and certified

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: checks are different.  Well, first of all, note that he doesn't necessarily -- he doesn't

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: disclaim them.  He says, well, we're not necessarily saying it.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: cashier's checks and certified checks, as the ABA brief points out. There have been qui tam lawsuits that have been filed. He says, well, cashier's checks aren't prepaid. Most cashier's and certified checks are prepaid.  The only ones that aren't prepaid are the ones in which banks are paying their own expenses, and our brief explains why we think those types of checks are covered under the statute.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: -- you had said -- or, excuse me, Justice --Justice Jackson, you had said the question in

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: this case is, what is the field that Congress occupied?  Congress knew exactly how to write the statute they want. They had the 1966 example.  They didn't do that here.  They wrote

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: And if you define, Justice Jackson, a

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: money order as anything that transmits money that is prepaid, you blow up the statute.  It means you can't explain what "traveler's checks" means. You can't explain what is left for "other similar written instruments."  Everything would be a money order.  Nothing would be similar to a --nothing would be similar to it.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: And that's why Congress -- we think

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: you should look to the rationales behind what Congress did.  You pointed to the legislative history and the Treasury Department, but th e

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: Treasury Department just says essentially that this is a belt -and-suspenders fix.  It doesn't

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: say that --it doesn't say that -- that -- that

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: -- something like teller's checks, which the Hunt Commission defined as being a third- party

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: And, finally and last, if you adopt

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: our solution, the common law, it incentivizes

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: exactly the kind of concerns that Justice Alito was worried about in Yee. It avoids any

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: questions about these other instruments, from

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: gift cards to cashier's checks to bearer's bonds and the like, and it avoids threatening the common law primary rule because a primary rule is creditor addresses.  And, Justice Thomas, your opinion in Delaware said that has venerable, old roots going all the way back to Old England.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: If they win, forget about place of

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: incorporation.  If they win, the primary rule of the FDA will control, which is to move away from last creditors' addresses.  That is something that there has been zero support that my friend has offered on the other side for, and that's why that old presumption that you read statutes to avoid derogation of the common law has special force here.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: We don't doubt, can you read the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: statute the way my friend does?  You can.  But, if you do so, it doesn't make sense of the

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: statute and threatens all sorts of other financial instruments.  And as the ABA says,

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: that's something you should be really, really

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: concerned about in this unique area, particularly because, as Justice Sotomayor

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: points out, this litigation can go all the way back to 1974 and unwind not just the two

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: disputed instruments here but every other financial instrument.

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: The safe thing to do is what you've

Speaker: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: I --I --I
Text: done in case after case, which is to say, if we're concerned about equity, that's something for Congress.  It's something for the states. It's not for this Court.
